Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Summary of Final Average Pay Plan Provisions
Accrued Service Full-time employees: 190 hours of service are credited if at least one hour is worked during a month.
One year of service is credited for 2,280 or more hours worked during the plan year. Partial service is
credited based upon the ratio of hours of service to 2,280.
Other employees: One year of service is credited for 1,900 or more hours of service during a Plan
Year. Partial service is credited based upon the ratio of hour of service to 1,900.
Service accruals for traditional KRIP benefits were frozen as of December 31, 2014.
Total Service The aggregate of all periods of employment.
Vesting Service One year of Vesting Service is credited for 365 day of service.
One day of service is credited if participant was an employee on that day.
Normal Retirement Date The first day of the month following attainment of age 65. (Special provisions apply to certain aircraft
pilots.)
Normal Retirement Benefit The sum of 1.3% of Average Compensation up to the Average Social security wage base plus 1.6% of
Average Compensation in excess of the Average Social Security wage base, multiplied by Accrued
Service up to 35 years. The calculated benefit is increased by 1/12 of 1% for each month of Credited
Service in excess of 35 years.
Early Retirement Eligibility All participants on the first of the month following attainment of age 55 and completion of ten years
of Total Service.
In addition, participants with Credited Service after April 19, 1990 and before January 1, 1996 may
retire on the first of the month following attainment of combined age and Total Service equaling 75.
Effective April 1, 2020 current employees who are age 60 or older, with 30 or more years of Total
Service and have a Traditional KRIP benefit may take an in-service distribution of their Traditional
KRIP benefit starting at age 60.

Late Retirement Benefits Prior to June 1, 2018, for employees who remain in service beyond age 65, the retirement benefits are
based upon Average Compensation and Credited Service at the employee's postponed retirement
date.
Effective June 1, 2018, in the event that an employee does not elect commence benefits as of age 65,
the employee’s benefit will be actuarially adjusted for any period between (a) the later of the
employees Normal Retirement Date and June 1, 2018 and (b) the employees Annuity Starting Date for
which payments are not made. Accruals under the cash balance plan for post-Normal Retirement
Date employment will be taken into account when determining whether an actuarial adjustment is
required. No actuarial adjustment is required for periods prior to June 1, 2018 when a Participant’s
benefit was subject to suspension.
Vesting Participants are 100% vested.
Disability Eligibility All employees receiving benefits under the long-term disability plan who have attained age 65, or
attained eligibility for Early Retirement Benefit based on Total Service (at the date of disability).
Disability Benefit The Normal or Early Retirement benefit calculated assuming Accrued Service continues to accrue
from the date of disability to retirement age. This benefit may not be greater than the amount
payable under the long-term disability plan, but in no event less than a participant's accrued benefit.

benefits calculated as if they were retiring on that date. Any payment from the KRIP will offset the
participant's long-term disability benefit. Disability benefits from the KRIP are payable only after
retirement eligibility (either Early or Normal) based on participant election. No additional service

benefit will be further reduced by 1/24 of 1% for each full or partial month that the option was in
effect.
Preretirement Survivor Spouses or domestic partners of active employees who die after becoming eligible for Vested
Income Basic Benefit Benefits. Spouses must have been married for at least one year prior to the employee's death. If the
Eligibility employee has no eligible spouse, dependent children and dependent parents are also eligible.

Summary of Cash Balance Plan Provisions
Eligibility for Participation Employees of Eastman Kodak Company and certain of its affiliates hired on or after March 1, 1999.
All eligible employees hired prior to March 1, 1999 were given a one-time choice of remaining covered
under the final pay benefit formula or being covered under the cash balance formula effective

earn benefits under the cash balance formula.
Compensation Salaries, wages, overtime pay, shift allowance, commissions, rate performance bonuses, and
Management Annual Performance Plan / Management Variable Compensation Plan payments for
duties performed plus allowances received for periods of authorized absence. Compensation is
subject to the legislated maximum.
Pay Credits For non-hourly active employees, 12% of monthly compensation. For hourly active employees, 13% of
monthly compensation.
Interest Crediting Rate One-twelfth of the annual interest rate on 30-year Treasurys for the second full calendar month
preceding the current month.
Interest Credits The beginning-of-the-month Cash Balance Account multiplied by the Interest Crediting Rate for the
prior month.
Cash Balance Account The sum of a participant's Opening Pay Credits, Pay Credits and Interest Credits.
Opening Pay Credits The amount of Pay Credits credited to the participant's Cash Balance Account as determined on
December 31, 1999.
Formerly Grandfathered participants, who remained in the Final Average Pay Plan after December 31,
1999 and whose final average pay benefits were subsequently frozen as of December 31, 2014 do not
have Opening Pay Credits. Their benefit is equal to their frozen final average pay benefit plus the
accumulated pay and interest credits since their entry into the Cash Balance Plan.
Actuarial Equivalent A benefit of equal value based on the 30-year Treasury rate for the second full month preceding the
commencement of benefits and the mortality table prescribed under Internal Revenue Code Section
417(e).
Vesting Service One year of Vesting Service is credited for 365 days of service. One day of service is credited if
participant was an employee on that day.
Pension Benefit at A monthly benefit equal to the Actuarial Equivalent of the participant's Cash Balance Account.
Termination Participants who elected to be covered under the cash balance provisions will have a minimum
benefit equal to their December 31, 1999 KRIP Final Average Pay benefit.
Preretirement Death Benefit Designated beneficiaries of vested participants.

Schedule SB, Part V – Statement of Actuarial Assumptions/Methods
Attachment to 2024 Form 5500 Schedule SB
EIN/PN 16-0417150/001
Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Actuarial Methods for Funding and Present Value of Accrued Benefits
Liability Valuation Method
Funding Target and Target Normal Cost as Defined in PPA
The Funding Target is defined to be the present value of the benefits accrued or earned at the valuation date. The earned
benefits include retirement-type benefits and ancillary benefits (1.430(d)-1(c)(1)(i)). If the amount of a benefit that is
expected to be paid is neither a function of the accrued benefit at the time the benefit is expected to be paid nor a function
of the participant's service at that time, then the portion of the benefit taken into account for purposes of determining the
Funding Target for a plan year is based on the proportion of a participant's service as of the first day of the plan year
relative to the service the participant will have when the participant decrements. The portion of the benefit that is taken
into account in the Target Normal Cost is the increase in the proportional benefit for the plan year (1.430(d)-1(c)(1)(ii)(C)).
The determination of the Funding Target and Target Normal Cost of a Plan for a plan year is not permitted to take into
account any limitations or anticipated limitations under section 436 (1.430(d)-1(c)(1)(iii)).
The Target Normal Cost is the present value of all the benefits expected to accrue or to be earned during the year (benefits
attributable to services performed in a prior year that are increased by reason of a compensation increase in the current
year are treated as having accrued during the current year). Plan administrative expenses paid (or expected to be paid)
from Actuarial Value of Assets for a plan year are not reflected in the determination of a plan's Funding Target for that plan
year (1.430(d)-1(c)(2)), but are reflected in the determination of a plan’s Target Normal Cost.
Generally if insurance contracts are held by the Plan, they are included in Actuarial Value of Assets and the related benefits
are included in the liability. In the case of benefits that are funded through insurance contracts purchased from an
insurance company licensed under the laws of a State, the Plan is permitted to exclude the benefits from the liability and
the insurance policy from the assets, but only to the extent that the right to receive benefits is an irrevocable contractual
right based on premiums paid prior to the valuation date (1.430(d)-1(c)(3)).
The determination of a Plan's Funding Target and Target Normal Cost for a plan year is based on Plan provisions that are
adopted no later than the valuation date for the plan year and that become effective during that plan year. Section
412(d)(2) applies for purposes of determining whether a Plan amendment is treated as having been adopted on the first
day of the plan year (including a Plan amendment adopted within two and one half months after the close of the plan year)
(1.430(d)-1(d)).
For maximum deductible purposes, the cushion amount is equal to the sum of 50 percent of the Funding Target for the
plan year and the amount the Funding Target for the plan year would increase if the Plan were to take into account
increases in compensation which are expected to occur in succeeding plan years. If the Plan does not base benefits for
service to date on compensation, increases in benefits which are expected to occur in succeeding plan years (determined
on the basis of the average annual increase in benefits over the six preceding plan years) are taken into account in lieu of
expected increases in compensation. For plans that have less than 100 participants, increases in benefits for highly
compensated employees as a result of Plan amendments within the last two years are excluded from the calculation of the
cushion amount.

Schedule SB, Part V – Statement of Actuarial Assumptions/Methods
Attachment to 2024 Form 5500 Schedule SB
EIN/PN 16-0417150/001
Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Actuarial Methods for Funding and Present Value of Accrued Benefits
Asset Valuation Method
Actuarial Value of Assets are determined using the two-year averaging method as set forth in Notice 2009-22. Under this
method, the Actuarial Value of Assets is the average of the fair market value of the assets on the valuation date and the
adjusted fair Market Value of Assets determined as of the two prior determination dates. The adjusted fair Market Value of
Assets as of a determination date is the Market Value of Assets on that date, increased by contributions that were not
included in the plan’s asset balance on the determination date and decreased by benefits and administrative expenses
between that determination date and the valuation date plus an adjustment for expected earnings as the sum of the
expected earnings separately determined for each period between the determination date and the valuation date. The
calculated value is then further constrained to be no more than 110% of the Market Value of Assets plus discounted
receivable contributions and no less than 90% of the Market Value of Assets plus discounted contributions.
Procedures
Financial and census data: Financial data was submitted by the Trustee and census data was submitted by the employer.
Information provided was reviewed for internal consistency and we have no reason to doubt its substantial accuracy.
No benefits of materiality were excluded from the valuation of the liabilities.
The limitations of the Internal Revenue Code 415(b) and 401(a)(17) have been incorporated into our calculations.
No liability is included for participants who terminated without vesting in their benefit prior to the valuation date.
The employer provided us with the data on its employees as of the valuation date, but only those employees who have
completed the Plan’s eligibility requirements are included in the valuation of liabilities.
Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits (ASC 960)
For active participants, the accrued pension benefits as of the valuation date and payable from the assumed retirement
age were determined based on actual plan compensation history for each participant. For inactive participants, accrued
benefits were either supplied by the Company or estimated. The Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits was
determined by multiplying the accrued pension benefits by single premium cost factors based on the applicable actuarial
assumptions for accrued benefits.
Model Use
Actuarial Standard of Practice No. 56 – Modeling requires disclosure of certain information regarding the actuary’s use of
models when issuing actuarial reports for work performed on or after October 1, 2020. For this valuation, the liability
calculations were determined using industry-leading defined benefit valuation software developed and maintained by a
third-party vendor. The model was designed specifically for the measurement of defined benefit pension liabilities and the
actuary has updated the applicable parameters for the specific plan provisions and assumptions selected for this valuation.
Method Changes Since Last Year
There were no method changes since the prior valuation.

INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT
To the Participants and Plan Administrator of the
Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of the Kodak Retirement Income Plan (the Plan), an
employee benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA),
which comprise the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023,
the related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, and the
related notes to the financial statements.
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the net
assets available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in its net
assets available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America.
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United
States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are
required to be independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance
with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we
have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Emphasis of Matter Regarding Going Concern
The accompanying financial statements have been prepared assuming that the Eastman Kodak
Company (Plan Sponsor) will continue as a going concern. As discussed in Note 11 to the financial
statements, the Plan Sponsor has identified certain matters that raise substantial doubt about its ability
to continue as a going concern. The financial statements do not include any adjustments that might
result from the outcome of this uncertainty. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter.
Emphasis of Matter Regarding Plan Termination
We draw attention to Note 1 to the financial statements, which describes the decision made by the
Plan Sponsor to terminate the Plan. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter.

Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for
the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair
presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or
error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions
or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue
as a going concern within one year after the date that the financial statements are issued or available
to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan’s transactions that are presented
and disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the Plan’s provisions, including
maintaining sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due
or which may become due to such participants.
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole
are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report
that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute
assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will
always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement
resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion,
forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements
are considered material if, there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they
would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we:
 Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
 Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due
to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such
procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures
in the financial statements.
 Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the Plan’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is
expressed.
 Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
2

 Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the
aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going concern
for a reasonable period of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters,
the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-
related matters that we identified during the audit.
Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
Our audits were conducted for the purpose of forming an opinion on the financial statements as a
whole. The supplemental schedule of assets (held at end of year) as of December 31, 2024 and
schedule of reportable transactions for the year ended December 31, 2024 are presented for purposes
of additional analysis and are not a required part of the financial statements but are supplementary
information required by the Department of Labor’s (DOL’s) Rules and Regulations for Reporting and
Disclosure under ERISA. Such information is the responsibility of management and was derived from
and relates directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial
statements. The information has been subjected to the auditing procedures applied in the audits of the
financial statements and certain additional procedures, including comparing and reconciling such
information directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial
statements or to the financial statements themselves, and other additional procedures in accordance
with GAAS.
In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental
schedules, including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the DOL’s Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
In our opinion, the information in the accompanying schedules is fairly stated, in all material respects,
in relation to the financial statements as a whole, and the form and content are presented in conformity
with the DOL’s Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan
The Kodak Retirement Income Plan (the Plan or KRIP) is a defined benefit pension plan of a
controlled group of corporations consisting of Eastman Kodak Company (the Company or
Kodak) and some of its domestic subsidiaries operating in the United States. The principal
provisions of the Plan are described below and are provided for general information purposes
only. Participants should refer to the Plan document for a more complete description of the
Plan’s provisions. The Plan is subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of
1974, as amended (ERISA).
Plan Actions
During 2024, the Company, in conjunction with the Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Committee (KRIPCO), implemented various actions designed to preserve and maximize the
value of KRIP’s over-funding by reducing investment risk and improving the overall liquidity
of KRIP. In connection with this, the Plan initiated the redemption of a substantial majority of
KRIP’s hedge fund and limited partnership investments.
On November 20, 2024, the Kodak Retirement Income Plan Trust (the Trust), in its capacity
as holder of assets for the benefit of KRIP, entered into a Purchase and Sale Agreement with a
third-party related to the sale of a portion of KRIP’s private equity and certain other illiquid
investments (collectively, KRIP Illiquid Assets). Pursuant to this agreement, on December 31,
2024, the Trust sold KRIP Illiquid Assets for a cash purchase price of $510 million, which was
received upon closing.
In addition, the Trust entered into Purchase and Sale Agreements with four other investors for
a portion of the remaining KRIP Illiquid Assets. On December 31, 2024, the Trust sold to these
investors KRIP Illiquid Assets for a purchase price of $49 million, of which $33 million was
received in cash on December 31, 2024, $7 million was received in cash in January 2025 and
$9 million is payable on a deferred basis on December 31, 2025.
KRIP received net distributions in 2024 related to the sale of these assets of approximately $43
million and cash proceeds of $543 million. The $7 million cash received in January 2025 and
the $9 million of deferred proceeds was recorded as a receivable as of December 31, 2024. As
a result, the discount to Net Asset Value (NAV) of KRIP Illiquid Assets sold pursuant to the
above transactions was approximately $238 million as of December 31, 2024.
On January 21, 2025, the Board of Directors of Kodak approved the termination of KRIP
effective March 31, 2025, and no further benefits will accrue under KRIP following such date.
In addition, the Board of Directors approved a defined benefit retirement plan (the Kodak Cash
Balance Plan) as a replacement for KRIP which became effective on March 1, 2025 for new
hires and becomes effective April 1, 2025 for current employees. The benefits under the Kodak
Cash Balance Plan are substantially the same as those under the cash balance feature of KRIP.
6

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Actions - Continued
The Plan’s liabilities will be satisfied through a combination of lump sum distributions to
active and terminated vested participants who elect a lump sum distribution and the purchase
of an annuity from an insurance company with respect to existing Plan annuity obligations for
current retirees and beneficiaries and annuity obligations arising from the termination to active
and terminated vested participants who do not elect to receive lump sum distributions. The
participant settlement election process ended on August 15, 2025. The Company intends to
finalize the purchase of an annuity contract during October 2025. The cost to satisfy the Plan’s
liabilities will be affected by a variety of factors including interest rate fluctuations, the portion
of active and terminated vested participants who elect lump-sum distributions, the premium
payable to purchase the annuity, and other actuarial factors used to calculate the value of the
Plan’s ongoing annuity obligations. While the Plan has hedging arrangements in place
designed to hedge interest rates for practically all of the Plan’s liabilities, a significant portion
of those arrangements are linked to fluctuations in US treasury rates and would not hedge
against changes to the difference between the discount rates used to value the Plan’s liabilities
and US treasury rates (i.e., the credit spread) or non-interest rate factors that may influence the
amount of the Plan’s liabilities.
After the Plan’s liabilities and applicable legal requirements have been satisfied, the Plan’s
surplus assets would revert to the Company as the settlor of the Plan subject to an excise tax.
The Company expects that it would direct the transfer of or otherwise contribute a portion of
the surplus assets (which may include all or a significant portion of remaining non-cash assets)
to the Kodak Cash Balance Plan. The Plan expects to distribute excess proceeds to the
Company and the Kodak Cash Balance Plan in December 2025; however, this time frame is
subject to factors beyond the Company’s control including (i) the availability of an annuity
product to satisfy the Plan’s annuity obligations at an acceptable cost and on acceptable terms,
(ii) the continued conversion of investments into cash or other liquid assets at the pace currently
anticipated, and (iii) regulatory review and approval of various aspects of the terms of the Plan,
the Plan’s activities, and the termination and liquidation process.
7

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Benefit
The Plan includes a cash balance formula for all employees of the Company hired after
February 28, 1999 and employees who elected to switch to the cash balance formula.
Retirement benefits under this formula are expressed as an account balance. Employees of the
Company hired after February 28, 1999 and participants who elected the cash balance formula
had their benefits calculated under the original KRIP method until December 31, 1999. On
January 1, 2000, these participants’ cash balance accounts were equal to the lump sum value
of their December 31, 1999 KRIP benefit calculated under the original formula. Beginning
January 1, 2000, each account earns a 4% compensation credit plus interest at the 30-year
Treasury bond rate, on a two month lag, based on their account balance.
For those hired on or before February 28, 1999 who have not elected to participate under the
cash balance formula, retirement income benefits of the Plan are determined by a unit credit
benefit type formula based on the employee’s average participating compensation and years of
accrued service, as these terms are defined in the Plan.
Participants credited with an hour of service on or after January 1, 2015 are 100% vested in
their accrued retirement benefit, payable upon early or normal retirement date, as defined in
the Plan. Participants with no hours of service on or after January 1, 2015 are fully vested after
three years of vesting service, as defined in the Plan. However, employees who terminate
before completing the three-year service requirement forfeit the right to receive any portion of
their accrued benefit. Participants with no hours of service after January 1, 2008, are fully
vested after five years of vesting service.
Benefit payments from the Plan may be paid either in the form of a straight life annuity, a
contingent annuity or a lump sum payment, except that, in the case of married retirees, the
normal form of benefit is paid in the form of a 50% joint and survivor annuity unless such form
of payment is expressly rejected by the subject retiree. A decision to elect other than a 50%
joint and survivor annuity must be agreed to in writing by the spouse.
The Plan provides unreduced retirement benefits to employees who are age 65 with any amount
of service. Employees are eligible for early retirement benefits at age 55 with at least 10 years
of service.
Effective April 1, 2020, a participant who has not terminated employment but has attained age
60 with 30 or more years of service, and who was employed prior to January 1, 1996, may
commence benefits in the form of a monthly annuity.
The Plan allows for Special Termination Programs (the Programs). The Programs allow for
enhanced retirement benefits for eligible participants with release dates after January 1, 2007
and before September 8, 2022, and between November 1, 2022 and October 31, 2025.
8

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Benefit - Continued
Effective January 1, 2015, participants in the traditional pension formula now participate in the
cash balance formula and are eligible for a benefit equal to the sum of the pre-2015 traditional
benefit and the post-2014 cash balance benefit. In addition, credits under the cash balance
formula increased from 4% of monthly compensation to 7% of monthly compensation.
Effective January 1, 2016, employees classified as nonexempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 8% of monthly compensation.
Effective January 1, 2020, employees classified as exempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 9% of monthly compensation and employees
classified as non-exempt covered employees will receive a pay credit of 10% of monthly
compensation.
Effective January 1, 2022, employees classified as exempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 12% of monthly compensation and employees
classified as non-exempt covered employees will receive a pay credit of 13% of monthly
compensation.
In addition to the foregoing, a one-time additional pay credit will be provided to covered
employees who were hired or most recently rehired prior to May 1, 2022 and are covered
employees actively employed as of May 31, 2022, with the amount of the pay credit to be equal
to the amount specified by the Company for such covered employee.
Effective June 30, 2023, the Plan was amended to provide a one-time additional pay credit to
covered employees who were hired or most recently rehired prior to June 1, 2023 and are
covered employees actively employed as of June 30, 2023, with the amount of the pay credit
for each covered employee to be equal to the amount specified by the Company for such
covered employee.
Plan Administration
The Plan is administered by KRIPCO, which is the Plan Administrator and named fiduciary.
BNY Mellon Bank, N.A. (Mellon or the Plan Trustee) is the trustee and BNY Mellon Asset
Management is the record keeper. During 2024, KRIPCO outsourced the investment
management of KRIP to NEPC, LLC. Costs related to administering the Plan are paid by the
Plan or the Company.

Note 2 Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Basis of Accounting
The Plan’s financial statements have been prepared on the accrual basis of accounting in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America
(GAAP).
Subsequent Events
In preparing the financial statements, management has evaluated all events and transactions
for potential recognition or disclosure through October 15, 2025, the date the financial
statements were available to be issued.
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to
make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, and
changes therein, disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities and the actuarial present value
of accumulated plan benefits at the date of the financial statements. Actual results could differ
from those estimates.
Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments to participants are recorded when paid.
Administrative Expenses
The Plan’s administrative expenses are paid out of the Plan.
Risks and Uncertainties
Investments of the Plan are exposed to various risks, such as interest rate, credit, and market
fluctuations. Market risks include global events which could impact the value of investment
securities, such as inflation, a pandemic or international conflict. Due to the level of risk
associated with these securities and the level of uncertainty related to changes in their values,
it is at least reasonably possible that changes in their values will occur in the near term and that
such changes could materially affect the amounts reported in the statements of net assets
available for benefits.
Plan contributions are made and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits is
reported based on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee
demographics, all of which are subject to change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimates
and assumptions process, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in these estimates and
assumptions in the near term would be material to the financial statements.

Note 3 Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are reported at fair value. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an
asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the
measurement date.
The Plan follows the fair value measurement guidance required by accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America for financial and nonfinancial assets and
liabilities. That guidance defines fair value and provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes
the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest
priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1
measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The
three levels of the fair value hierarchy are described below:
Level 1 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical
assets or liabilities in active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
Level 2 Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
• Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
• Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
• Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability;
• Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market
data by correlation or other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be
observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
Level 3 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair
value measurement.
The asset or liability’s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on
the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement. Valuation
techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of
unobservable inputs.
Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for investments measured at
fair value. There have been no changes in the methodologies used at December 31, 2024 and
2023.
United States Government Securities and Corporate and Municipal Debt Securities: Valued
on the basis of closing prices on the last trading day of the reporting period.
Common Stocks, Futures Variation Margin, Interest Bearing Cash and Preferred Stocks:
Valued on the basis of closing prices on the last trading day of the reporting period as
reported by the investment manager.

Note 3 Investment Valuation and Income Recognition - Continued
Liquidity Risk
Approximately 6% of total investments as of December 31, 2024 are invested in real estate,
private equity and natural resource funds. These funds do not permit investor redemption
requests, rather they process distributions to investors as the general partner of each fund
liquidates underlying investments over the life of each fund. In the event that these funds were
sold in the near term on a secondary market, they may be sold at a discount to the latest
valuations.
Purchases and sales of securities are recorded on a trade-date basis. Dividends are recorded on
the ex-dividend date. Interest is recorded on the accrual basis. Net appreciation (depreciation)
includes the Plan’s gains and losses on investments bought and sold as well as held during the
year.
Note 4 Derivative and Other Financial Instruments
Derivative Financial Instruments
The Plan is a user of derivative financial instruments, including debt and equity futures. The
Plan utilizes derivative financial instruments for the purposes of asset allocation (i.e., as a
substitute for physical investing), to hedge foreign currency risk and to manage interest rate
and other market risks. The substantial majority of the derivative financial instruments entered
into by the Plan are exchange traded where the exchange acts as the counterparty to the
transaction. All derivatives are reported in the financial statements as assets or liabilities
measured at fair value. Changes in fair value are reflected as changes in net assets. Credit risk
on such transactions is limited to the failure of the regulated exchange, which is considered a
remote possibility. For non-exchange-traded instruments, the Plan transacts only with major,
credit-worthy financial institutions and monitors and limits the amounts held with any one
counterparty to minimize counterparty risk. KRIPCO maintains separate limited liability trusts
for each direct account which invests in derivatives.
Futures Contracts
The Plan invests in a variety of equity and debt futures contracts to manage exposure to the
market. Daily variation margin payments are made to or received from the counterparty for
changes in the market value of futures contracts and are recorded as realized gains and losses.
The Plan is required by statute to maintain certain assets on deposit to collateralize its
obligations under its futures contracts. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, approximately $.3
million and $11 million, respectively, in cash and securities collateral were on deposit to fulfill
these requirements. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, the net contract size or notional amount
held by the Plan had approximately $574 million and $384 million of equity and debt security
futures contracts, respectively. A summary of the open futures as of December 31, 2024 and
2023 is presented on Page 15:

Note 5 Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump sum
distributions that are attributable under the Plan’s provisions to the service employees have
rendered to the valuation date. They include benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired or
terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died, and
(c) present employees or their beneficiaries. The accumulated plan benefits for active
employees are based on their average participating compensation. The actuarial present value
of accumulated plan benefits is determined for 2024 and 2023 by Deloitte Consulting LLP,
and is the amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated
plan benefits to reflect the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the
probability of payment (by means of decrements such as for death, disability, withdrawal, or
retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date of payment. The significant
actuarial assumptions used in the valuation as of January 1, 2024 and 2023 are as follows:
a. 2024 – Life expectancy of participants: Base Table – PRI-2012 Mortality Tables.
Kodak selected base table based on review of plan experience. Longevity
Improvement - Projection RPEC Scale MP-2021. This scale uses the RPEC Scale
MP-2021 projection with adjustments to reflect expected excess future mortality of
4% for 2024 grading down to 0% over four years.
2023 - Life expectancy of participants: Base Table – PRI-2012 Mortality Tables.
Kodak selected base table based on review of plan experience. Longevity
Improvement - Projection RPEC Scale MP-2021. This scale uses the RPEC Scale
MP-2021 projection with adjustments to reflect expected excess future mortality of
5% for 2023 grading down to 0% over five years.
b. Age of retirement: Retirement ages used are based on a weighted average table,
based on the actuary’s review of the Plan’s experience;
c. Assumed Rate of Return: 7.1% in 2024 and 7.5% in 2023;
The foregoing actuarial assumptions are based on the presumption that the Plan will continue.
The effect of the Plan termination discussed in Note 1 has not been reflected in the
accompanying actuarial valuation data as of January 1, 2024.

Note 6 Funding Policy
Retirement income benefits are financed solely by contributions made by Kodak. The
employees make no contributions to the Plan. Kodak makes contributions to the Plan as
permitted or required by government laws and regulations. Minimum funding requirements
under ERISA guidelines have been met.
Note 7 Credit Facility
The Plan had a Credit Facility Agreement with M&T Bank under the terms of which the Plan
could borrow up to $50,000,000. This credit agreement included interest at the Secured
Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) plus 95 basis points. The credit facility was collateralized
by the assets of the Plan and had a maturity date of November 29, 2024, which was not renewed
upon maturity. There was no balance outstanding as of December 31, 2024 or 2023.

Note 8 Federal Income Tax Status
On April 1, 2021, the Plan received a favorable tax determination letter from the Internal
Revenue Service (IRS) in which the IRS stated that the Plan is in compliance with the
applicable requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. Although the Plan has been amended
since the period covered by the determination letter, the Plan Administrator and the Plan’s tax
counsel believe that the Plan is currently designed and being operated in compliance with the
applicable requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. Therefore, no provision for income
taxes has been included in the Plan’s financial statements.
Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America require Plan
management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability (or asset)
if the Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained
upon examination by the IRS. The Plan Administrator has analyzed the tax positions taken by
the Plan, and has concluded that as of December 31, 2024, there are no uncertain positions
taken or expected to be taken that would require recognition of a liability (or asset) or
disclosure in the financial statements. The Plan was under audit by the United States
Department of Labor. As of the date of these financial statements, the Department of Labor
closed its investigation and there were no findings that would have a significant impact on the
Plan or that would require material change to the financial statements.

Schedule SB, line 24 – Change in Actuarial Assumptions
EIN 16-0417150 / PIN 001
Change in Assumptions
• The non-investment administrative expenses assumed were updated from $6,270,000 in 2023 to
$7,710,000 in 2024. The update of expense reflects Kodak's most recent experience.
• Salary scale is adjusted to reflect 1.5% increment for year 2024 and revert to previous merit rates from year
2025 onwards as of December 31, 2023.
• The lump sum interest rate for Pre-96 grandfathered benefits was updated to 4%.
Justification for Changes
• The expense assumption is based on Kodak's most recent experience and expectation for current year's PBGC
premiums.
• The salary scale assumption reflects management's expectations for pay increases during the upcoming year.
• The lump sum interest rate for Pre-96 grandfathered benefits was updated based on current IRS guidance and
market information as of the measurement date.

INDEPENDENT AUDITOR’S REPORT
To the Participants and Plan Administrator of the
Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Opinion
We have audited the financial statements of the Kodak Retirement Income Plan (the Plan), an
employee benefit plan subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA),
which comprise the statements of net assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024 and 2023,
the related statements of changes in net assets available for benefits for the years then ended, and the
related notes to the financial statements.
In our opinion, the accompanying financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the net
assets available for benefits of the Plan as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, and the changes in its net
assets available for benefits for the years then ended, in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America.
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United
States of America (GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are
required to be independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance
with the relevant ethical requirements relating to our audits. We believe that the audit evidence we
have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our audit opinion.
Emphasis of Matter Regarding Going Concern
The accompanying financial statements have been prepared assuming that the Eastman Kodak
Company (Plan Sponsor) will continue as a going concern. As discussed in Note 11 to the financial
statements, the Plan Sponsor has identified certain matters that raise substantial doubt about its ability
to continue as a going concern. The financial statements do not include any adjustments that might
result from the outcome of this uncertainty. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter.
Emphasis of Matter Regarding Plan Termination
We draw attention to Note 1 to the financial statements, which describes the decision made by the
Plan Sponsor to terminate the Plan. Our opinion is not modified with respect to this matter.

Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for
the design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair
presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or
error.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions
or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue
as a going concern within one year after the date that the financial statements are issued or available
to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the Plan, and determining that the Plan’s transactions that are presented
and disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the Plan’s provisions, including
maintaining sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due
or which may become due to such participants.
Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole
are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report
that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute
assurance and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with GAAS will
always detect a material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement
resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion,
forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements
are considered material if, there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they
would influence the judgment made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with GAAS, we:
 Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
 Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due
to fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such
procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures
in the financial statements.
 Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the Plan’s internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is
expressed.
 Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
2

 Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the
aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan’s ability to continue as a going concern
for a reasonable period of time.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters,
the planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-
related matters that we identified during the audit.
Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
Our audits were conducted for the purpose of forming an opinion on the financial statements as a
whole. The supplemental schedule of assets (held at end of year) as of December 31, 2024 and
schedule of reportable transactions for the year ended December 31, 2024 are presented for purposes
of additional analysis and are not a required part of the financial statements but are supplementary
information required by the Department of Labor’s (DOL’s) Rules and Regulations for Reporting and
Disclosure under ERISA. Such information is the responsibility of management and was derived from
and relates directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial
statements. The information has been subjected to the auditing procedures applied in the audits of the
financial statements and certain additional procedures, including comparing and reconciling such
information directly to the underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial
statements or to the financial statements themselves, and other additional procedures in accordance
with GAAS.
In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental
schedules, including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the DOL’s Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
In our opinion, the information in the accompanying schedules is fairly stated, in all material respects,
in relation to the financial statements as a whole, and the form and content are presented in conformity
with the DOL’s Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan
The Kodak Retirement Income Plan (the Plan or KRIP) is a defined benefit pension plan of a
controlled group of corporations consisting of Eastman Kodak Company (the Company or
Kodak) and some of its domestic subsidiaries operating in the United States. The principal
provisions of the Plan are described below and are provided for general information purposes
only. Participants should refer to the Plan document for a more complete description of the
Plan’s provisions. The Plan is subject to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of
1974, as amended (ERISA).
Plan Actions
During 2024, the Company, in conjunction with the Kodak Retirement Income Plan
Committee (KRIPCO), implemented various actions designed to preserve and maximize the
value of KRIP’s over-funding by reducing investment risk and improving the overall liquidity
of KRIP. In connection with this, the Plan initiated the redemption of a substantial majority of
KRIP’s hedge fund and limited partnership investments.
On November 20, 2024, the Kodak Retirement Income Plan Trust (the Trust), in its capacity
as holder of assets for the benefit of KRIP, entered into a Purchase and Sale Agreement with a
third-party related to the sale of a portion of KRIP’s private equity and certain other illiquid
investments (collectively, KRIP Illiquid Assets). Pursuant to this agreement, on December 31,
2024, the Trust sold KRIP Illiquid Assets for a cash purchase price of $510 million, which was
received upon closing.
In addition, the Trust entered into Purchase and Sale Agreements with four other investors for
a portion of the remaining KRIP Illiquid Assets. On December 31, 2024, the Trust sold to these
investors KRIP Illiquid Assets for a purchase price of $49 million, of which $33 million was
received in cash on December 31, 2024, $7 million was received in cash in January 2025 and
$9 million is payable on a deferred basis on December 31, 2025.
KRIP received net distributions in 2024 related to the sale of these assets of approximately $43
million and cash proceeds of $543 million. The $7 million cash received in January 2025 and
the $9 million of deferred proceeds was recorded as a receivable as of December 31, 2024. As
a result, the discount to Net Asset Value (NAV) of KRIP Illiquid Assets sold pursuant to the
above transactions was approximately $238 million as of December 31, 2024.
On January 21, 2025, the Board of Directors of Kodak approved the termination of KRIP
effective March 31, 2025, and no further benefits will accrue under KRIP following such date.
In addition, the Board of Directors approved a defined benefit retirement plan (the Kodak Cash
Balance Plan) as a replacement for KRIP which became effective on March 1, 2025 for new
hires and becomes effective April 1, 2025 for current employees. The benefits under the Kodak
Cash Balance Plan are substantially the same as those under the cash balance feature of KRIP.
6

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Actions - Continued
The Plan’s liabilities will be satisfied through a combination of lump sum distributions to
active and terminated vested participants who elect a lump sum distribution and the purchase
of an annuity from an insurance company with respect to existing Plan annuity obligations for
current retirees and beneficiaries and annuity obligations arising from the termination to active
and terminated vested participants who do not elect to receive lump sum distributions. The
participant settlement election process ended on August 15, 2025. The Company intends to
finalize the purchase of an annuity contract during October 2025. The cost to satisfy the Plan’s
liabilities will be affected by a variety of factors including interest rate fluctuations, the portion
of active and terminated vested participants who elect lump-sum distributions, the premium
payable to purchase the annuity, and other actuarial factors used to calculate the value of the
Plan’s ongoing annuity obligations. While the Plan has hedging arrangements in place
designed to hedge interest rates for practically all of the Plan’s liabilities, a significant portion
of those arrangements are linked to fluctuations in US treasury rates and would not hedge
against changes to the difference between the discount rates used to value the Plan’s liabilities
and US treasury rates (i.e., the credit spread) or non-interest rate factors that may influence the
amount of the Plan’s liabilities.
After the Plan’s liabilities and applicable legal requirements have been satisfied, the Plan’s
surplus assets would revert to the Company as the settlor of the Plan subject to an excise tax.
The Company expects that it would direct the transfer of or otherwise contribute a portion of
the surplus assets (which may include all or a significant portion of remaining non-cash assets)
to the Kodak Cash Balance Plan. The Plan expects to distribute excess proceeds to the
Company and the Kodak Cash Balance Plan in December 2025; however, this time frame is
subject to factors beyond the Company’s control including (i) the availability of an annuity
product to satisfy the Plan’s annuity obligations at an acceptable cost and on acceptable terms,
(ii) the continued conversion of investments into cash or other liquid assets at the pace currently
anticipated, and (iii) regulatory review and approval of various aspects of the terms of the Plan,
the Plan’s activities, and the termination and liquidation process.
7

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Benefit
The Plan includes a cash balance formula for all employees of the Company hired after
February 28, 1999 and employees who elected to switch to the cash balance formula.
Retirement benefits under this formula are expressed as an account balance. Employees of the
Company hired after February 28, 1999 and participants who elected the cash balance formula
had their benefits calculated under the original KRIP method until December 31, 1999. On
January 1, 2000, these participants’ cash balance accounts were equal to the lump sum value
of their December 31, 1999 KRIP benefit calculated under the original formula. Beginning
January 1, 2000, each account earns a 4% compensation credit plus interest at the 30-year
Treasury bond rate, on a two month lag, based on their account balance.
For those hired on or before February 28, 1999 who have not elected to participate under the
cash balance formula, retirement income benefits of the Plan are determined by a unit credit
benefit type formula based on the employee’s average participating compensation and years of
accrued service, as these terms are defined in the Plan.
Participants credited with an hour of service on or after January 1, 2015 are 100% vested in
their accrued retirement benefit, payable upon early or normal retirement date, as defined in
the Plan. Participants with no hours of service on or after January 1, 2015 are fully vested after
three years of vesting service, as defined in the Plan. However, employees who terminate
before completing the three-year service requirement forfeit the right to receive any portion of
their accrued benefit. Participants with no hours of service after January 1, 2008, are fully
vested after five years of vesting service.
Benefit payments from the Plan may be paid either in the form of a straight life annuity, a
contingent annuity or a lump sum payment, except that, in the case of married retirees, the
normal form of benefit is paid in the form of a 50% joint and survivor annuity unless such form
of payment is expressly rejected by the subject retiree. A decision to elect other than a 50%
joint and survivor annuity must be agreed to in writing by the spouse.
The Plan provides unreduced retirement benefits to employees who are age 65 with any amount
of service. Employees are eligible for early retirement benefits at age 55 with at least 10 years
of service.
Effective April 1, 2020, a participant who has not terminated employment but has attained age
60 with 30 or more years of service, and who was employed prior to January 1, 1996, may
commence benefits in the form of a monthly annuity.
The Plan allows for Special Termination Programs (the Programs). The Programs allow for
enhanced retirement benefits for eligible participants with release dates after January 1, 2007
and before September 8, 2022, and between November 1, 2022 and October 31, 2025.
8

KODAK RETIREMENT INCOME PLAN
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
DECEMBER 31, 2024 AND 2023
Note 1 Description of the Plan - Continued
Plan Benefit - Continued
Effective January 1, 2015, participants in the traditional pension formula now participate in the
cash balance formula and are eligible for a benefit equal to the sum of the pre-2015 traditional
benefit and the post-2014 cash balance benefit. In addition, credits under the cash balance
formula increased from 4% of monthly compensation to 7% of monthly compensation.
Effective January 1, 2016, employees classified as nonexempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 8% of monthly compensation.
Effective January 1, 2020, employees classified as exempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 9% of monthly compensation and employees
classified as non-exempt covered employees will receive a pay credit of 10% of monthly
compensation.
Effective January 1, 2022, employees classified as exempt covered employees will receive
credits under the cash balance formula of 12% of monthly compensation and employees
classified as non-exempt covered employees will receive a pay credit of 13% of monthly
compensation.
In addition to the foregoing, a one-time additional pay credit will be provided to covered
employees who were hired or most recently rehired prior to May 1, 2022 and are covered
employees actively employed as of May 31, 2022, with the amount of the pay credit to be equal
to the amount specified by the Company for such covered employee.
Effective June 30, 2023, the Plan was amended to provide a one-time additional pay credit to
covered employees who were hired or most recently rehired prior to June 1, 2023 and are
covered employees actively employed as of June 30, 2023, with the amount of the pay credit
for each covered employee to be equal to the amount specified by the Company for such
covered employee.
Plan Administration
The Plan is administered by KRIPCO, which is the Plan Administrator and named fiduciary.
BNY Mellon Bank, N.A. (Mellon or the Plan Trustee) is the trustee and BNY Mellon Asset
Management is the record keeper. During 2024, KRIPCO outsourced the investment
management of KRIP to NEPC, LLC. Costs related to administering the Plan are paid by the
Plan or the Company.

Note 2 Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
Basis of Accounting
The Plan’s financial statements have been prepared on the accrual basis of accounting in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America
(GAAP).
Subsequent Events
In preparing the financial statements, management has evaluated all events and transactions
for potential recognition or disclosure through October 15, 2025, the date the financial
statements were available to be issued.
Use of Estimates
The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires management to
make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, and
changes therein, disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities and the actuarial present value
of accumulated plan benefits at the date of the financial statements. Actual results could differ
from those estimates.
Payment of Benefits
Benefit payments to participants are recorded when paid.
Administrative Expenses
The Plan’s administrative expenses are paid out of the Plan.
Risks and Uncertainties
Investments of the Plan are exposed to various risks, such as interest rate, credit, and market
fluctuations. Market risks include global events which could impact the value of investment
securities, such as inflation, a pandemic or international conflict. Due to the level of risk
associated with these securities and the level of uncertainty related to changes in their values,
it is at least reasonably possible that changes in their values will occur in the near term and that
such changes could materially affect the amounts reported in the statements of net assets
available for benefits.
Plan contributions are made and the actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits is
reported based on certain assumptions pertaining to interest rates, inflation rates and employee
demographics, all of which are subject to change. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimates
and assumptions process, it is at least reasonably possible that changes in these estimates and
assumptions in the near term would be material to the financial statements.

Note 3 Investment Valuation and Income Recognition
Investments are reported at fair value. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an
asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the
measurement date.
The Plan follows the fair value measurement guidance required by accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America for financial and nonfinancial assets and
liabilities. That guidance defines fair value and provides a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes
the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest
priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1
measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). The
three levels of the fair value hierarchy are described below:
Level 1 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical
assets or liabilities in active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
Level 2 Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
• Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
• Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
• Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability;
• Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market
data by correlation or other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the Level 2 input must be
observable for substantially the full term of the asset or liability.
Level 3 Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair
value measurement.
The asset or liability’s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on
the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement. Valuation
techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of
unobservable inputs.
Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for investments measured at
fair value. There have been no changes in the methodologies used at December 31, 2024 and
2023.
United States Government Securities and Corporate and Municipal Debt Securities: Valued
on the basis of closing prices on the last trading day of the reporting period.
Common Stocks, Futures Variation Margin, Interest Bearing Cash and Preferred Stocks:
Valued on the basis of closing prices on the last trading day of the reporting period as
reported by the investment manager.

periodic provisions for redeeming fund shares at NAV. Instead, distributions from these funds
are primarily received as the underlying assets held by the funds can be realized. Investments
are primarily valued based on independent appraisals, discounted cash flow models, cost and
comparable market transactions. The NAV of funds in this category is reported monthly or
quarterly to the Plan by the fund administrators.

Note 3 Investment Valuation and Income Recognition - Continued
Liquidity Risk
Approximately 6% of total investments as of December 31, 2024 are invested in real estate,
private equity and natural resource funds. These funds do not permit investor redemption
requests, rather they process distributions to investors as the general partner of each fund
liquidates underlying investments over the life of each fund. In the event that these funds were
sold in the near term on a secondary market, they may be sold at a discount to the latest
valuations.
Purchases and sales of securities are recorded on a trade-date basis. Dividends are recorded on
the ex-dividend date. Interest is recorded on the accrual basis. Net appreciation (depreciation)
includes the Plan’s gains and losses on investments bought and sold as well as held during the
year.
Note 4 Derivative and Other Financial Instruments
Derivative Financial Instruments
The Plan is a user of derivative financial instruments, including debt and equity futures. The
Plan utilizes derivative financial instruments for the purposes of asset allocation (i.e., as a
substitute for physical investing), to hedge foreign currency risk and to manage interest rate
and other market risks. The substantial majority of the derivative financial instruments entered
into by the Plan are exchange traded where the exchange acts as the counterparty to the
transaction. All derivatives are reported in the financial statements as assets or liabilities
measured at fair value. Changes in fair value are reflected as changes in net assets. Credit risk
on such transactions is limited to the failure of the regulated exchange, which is considered a
remote possibility. For non-exchange-traded instruments, the Plan transacts only with major,
credit-worthy financial institutions and monitors and limits the amounts held with any one
counterparty to minimize counterparty risk. KRIPCO maintains separate limited liability trusts
for each direct account which invests in derivatives.
Futures Contracts
The Plan invests in a variety of equity and debt futures contracts to manage exposure to the
market. Daily variation margin payments are made to or received from the counterparty for
changes in the market value of futures contracts and are recorded as realized gains and losses.
The Plan is required by statute to maintain certain assets on deposit to collateralize its
obligations under its futures contracts. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, approximately $.3
million and $11 million, respectively, in cash and securities collateral were on deposit to fulfill
these requirements. At December 31, 2024 and 2023, the net contract size or notional amount
held by the Plan had approximately $574 million and $384 million of equity and debt security
futures contracts, respectively. A summary of the open futures as of December 31, 2024 and
2023 is presented on Page 15:

Note 5 Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump sum
distributions that are attributable under the Plan’s provisions to the service employees have
rendered to the valuation date. They include benefits expected to be paid to (a) retired or
terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who have died, and
(c) present employees or their beneficiaries. The accumulated plan benefits for active
employees are based on their average participating compensation. The actuarial present value
of accumulated plan benefits is determined for 2024 and 2023 by Deloitte Consulting LLP,
and is the amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust the accumulated
plan benefits to reflect the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the
probability of payment (by means of decrements such as for death, disability, withdrawal, or
retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date of payment. The significant
actuarial assumptions used in the valuation as of January 1, 2024 and 2023 are as follows:
a. 2024 – Life expectancy of participants: Base Table – PRI-2012 Mortality Tables.
Kodak selected base table based on review of plan experience. Longevity
Improvement - Projection RPEC Scale MP-2021. This scale uses the RPEC Scale
MP-2021 projection with adjustments to reflect expected excess future mortality of
4% for 2024 grading down to 0% over four years.
2023 - Life expectancy of participants: Base Table – PRI-2012 Mortality Tables.
Kodak selected base table based on review of plan experience. Longevity
Improvement - Projection RPEC Scale MP-2021. This scale uses the RPEC Scale
MP-2021 projection with adjustments to reflect expected excess future mortality of
5% for 2023 grading down to 0% over five years.
b. Age of retirement: Retirement ages used are based on a weighted average table,
based on the actuary’s review of the Plan’s experience;
c. Assumed Rate of Return: 7.1% in 2024 and 7.5% in 2023;
The foregoing actuarial assumptions are based on the presumption that the Plan will continue.
The effect of the Plan termination discussed in Note 1 has not been reflected in the
accompanying actuarial valuation data as of January 1, 2024.

Note 6 Funding Policy
Retirement income benefits are financed solely by contributions made by Kodak. The
employees make no contributions to the Plan. Kodak makes contributions to the Plan as
permitted or required by government laws and regulations. Minimum funding requirements
under ERISA guidelines have been met.
Note 7 Credit Facility
The Plan had a Credit Facility Agreement with M&T Bank under the terms of which the Plan
could borrow up to $50,000,000. This credit agreement included interest at the Secured
Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) plus 95 basis points. The credit facility was collateralized
by the assets of the Plan and had a maturity date of November 29, 2024, which was not renewed
upon maturity. There was no balance outstanding as of December 31, 2024 or 2023.

Note 8 Federal Income Tax Status
On April 1, 2021, the Plan received a favorable tax determination letter from the Internal
Revenue Service (IRS) in which the IRS stated that the Plan is in compliance with the
applicable requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. Although the Plan has been amended
since the period covered by the determination letter, the Plan Administrator and the Plan’s tax
counsel believe that the Plan is currently designed and being operated in compliance with the
applicable requirements of the Internal Revenue Code. Therefore, no provision for income
taxes has been included in the Plan’s financial statements.
Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America require Plan
management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and recognize a tax liability (or asset)
if the Plan has taken an uncertain position that more likely than not would not be sustained
upon examination by the IRS. The Plan Administrator has analyzed the tax positions taken by
the Plan, and has concluded that as of December 31, 2024, there are no uncertain positions
taken or expected to be taken that would require recognition of a liability (or asset) or
disclosure in the financial statements. The Plan was under audit by the United States
Department of Labor. As of the date of these financial statements, the Department of Labor
closed its investigation and there were no findings that would have a significant impact on the
Plan or that would require material change to the financial statements.
